title: 111_hr4779
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010" and extends temporary bonus depreciation for certain property. The Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010 extends the special allowance for certain property by changing the dates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010 extends the special allowance for certain property by changing dates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to January 1, 2011. Additionally, the election to accelerate the AMT and research credits in lieu of bonus depreciation is extended to 2010. The Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010 extends the special allowance for certain property by changing dates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to January 1, 2011. It also allows taxpayers who made the election under subparagraph (A) for their first taxable year ending after March 31, 2008 to elect not to have certain rules apply to extension property. The Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010 extends the special allowance for certain property by changing dates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to January 1, 2011. Taxpayers can elect to have a separate bonus depreciation amount computed and applied to eligible qualified property, whether extension property or not. If a taxpayer did not make the election for their first taxable year ending after March 31, 2008, they may elect to have certain rules apply to their first year. The paragraph applies to taxable years ending after December 31, 2009, and subsequent years. If the taxpayer elects, it only applies to eligible qualified property that is extension property. Extension property refers to property eligible solely due to the extension of the special allowance under paragraph (1). The Small Business Jobs and Tax Relief Act of 2010 allows for a $1,500 limit on the amount considered for each vehicle with an idling reduction device. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2009, in taxable years ending after that date. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN DEDUCTION FOR START-UP EXPENDITURES: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the deduction for start-up expenditures for taxable years beginning in 2010, 2011, or 2012. 

SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF CELLULAR TELEPHONES FROM LISTED PROPERTY: Removes cellular telephones from listed property. SEC. 5. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code regarding listed property and effective date for taxable years after January 1, 2009. Nonrecourse small business investment company loans from the Small Business Administration treated as amounts at risk. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to define qualified nonrecourse financing as financing that is qualified real property financing or qualified SBIC financing, with no personal liability for repayment and not convertible debt. Qualified real property financing is defined as financing borrowed by the taxpayer for holding real property, secured by real property used in the activity, and borrowed from a qualified person or government entity. The term 'qualified SBIC financing' refers to financing borrowed by a small business investment company, secured by property owned by the company, and borrowed from or guaranteed by the Small Business Administration. The amendments made by this section, under the authority of section 303(b) of the Act, involve conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. These amendments remove certain phrases related to real property activities. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF 100 PERCENT OF GAIN ON CERTAIN SMALL BUSINESS STOCK. SEC. 6 amends section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code to provide a 100% exclusion for qualified small business stock acquired during 2010. The effective date of these amendments is January 1, 2010. The amendments made by section 6 apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2009.
